(42) 46thConclusions,Minute 1, andW.M. (42) 62ndConclusions.)1. The War Cabinet had under consideration Memoranda bythe Lord President of the Council and the President of the Boardof Trade regarding the reorganisation of the coal-mining industry,the coal production programme for 1942-43, and the question of rationing the domestic consumption of fuel.The War Cabinet approved the proposals put forward by theLord President of the Council, and agreed that a comprehensive statement of the Governments policy for increasing the productionand restricting the consumption of coal should be embodied in a white Paper to be presented to Parliament on Wednesday, the3rd June.The War Cabinet-Invited the President of the Board of Trade to circulate a draft of the proposed White Paper for consideration bythe War Cabinet at their meeting on Monday, the 1st June.Supplies toRussia.(previous reference:W.M. (42) 64thConclusions,Minute 2.)2. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs informed the'War Cabinet that a Meeting was being held that afternoon toconsider the recent demand for an increase in military supplies toRussia. He was proposing to suggest that this matter should bedealt with on the basis of an increase of, say, 100 in the number of tanks to be included in the next convoy, but of no increase in thenumber of fighter aircraft.The War Cabinet-Invited the Foreign Secretary to arrange for this proposalto be examined by the Ministers concerned, as a matter of urgency.The Minister 3. The Prime Minister informed the War Cabinet that theof Production. Minister of Production was leaving for the United States ofAmerica on a short visit. The Lord President of the Council had undertaken to carry on the Minister's duties for him during his absence.The War Cabinet took note of this statement.Great George Street, S. W. 1,May 29, 1942.
SECRET.NO CIRCULATION.W.M. (43) 69.29th May. 1942 - 11 a.m.) MEETINGSORGANISED BYSOCIETIESCONNECTED WITHTHE COMMUNISTMOVEMENT.THE LORD PRIVY SEAL informed the WarCabinet that he had accepted an invitation to address a meeting on the 20th June to celebrate the entry of Russia into the war. The Home Secretary had certain views on the matter which he wished to put to the War Cabinet.THE HOME SECRETARY explained that,although the nominal sponsors of this meeting were a large number of persons of high standing and responsibility (the list of which was read to theWar Cabinet), the meeting was in fact organised by three bodies (Russia To-day, the Joint Committeefor Soviet Aid, and the National Council of British-Soviet Unity) all of which had associated with their administration persons closely connected with theCommunist Movement. This modus o-perandi was increasingly practised by the Communist Movement.He feared that if a Cabinet Minister addressed thismeeting, the result would be that these Societies wouldclaim publicly that they were above reproach.There was some discussion on the subjectthat the Government should itself organise a demonstration to celebrate the aniversary of Russia'sentry into the war and their coming alliance withthis country, and that this should be made a pretext for the Lord Privy Seal to say that as he had to address the Government meeting, he could not address the meeting organised by these three Societies.After some discussion, however, the view was taken that it was rather late in the day to makea change of this nature.The War Cabinet were informed that aMemorandum, dealing with the attitude which should betaken in regard to such Societies, was in preparation and would shortly be submitted to the War Cabinet.This would afford an opportunity for a policy to belaid down, after due consideration.Great George Street, S.W.1.
